home.history1: CHANGHYUN.me has been built, scrapped, and rebuilt probably ten times since 2015 ‚Äî not even kidding.
home.history2: It all started with just HTML and CSS, until I hit a wall and jumped into PHP.
home.history3: From there, I wandered through Wordpress and Node.js, and now?
home.history4: It's running on Next.js with a little help from Vercel.
home.history5: Below is a rough timeline of each version ‚Äî mostly based on memory, so take it with a grain of salt.
home.builtTitle: How It's Built ‚Äî And Why That Matters
home.built1: This version of CHANGHYUN.me is built with React and styled using TailwindCSS.
home.built2: It's fast, minimal, and flexible enough to keep evolving without starting over.
home.built3: I made a conscious decision to avoid traditional CSS altogether ‚Äî no SCSS, no BEM.
home.built4: Instead, I chose to stay fully within the Tailwind ecosystem, pushing its utility-first model to the edge.
home.built5: That constraint actually made things more fun and deliberate.
home.built6: I used to split my editor just to keep up with my own CSS.
home.built7: With Tailwind, I finally reclaimed half my screen.
home.built8: The site runs on Next.js ‚Äî mostly because it handles routing and rendering cleanly out of the box,
home.built9: and I've gotten used to how it balances flexibility with convention.
home.built11: The free tier covers everything I need for now, and I'm totally fine paying once it doesn't.
home.built12: I chose it because it saves me from hours of server setup (which always feels minor but ends up eating time),
home.built13: deployment is literally just git push, and things like SSL and basic security are pre-configured.
home.built14: For blog content, I built a custom parser that structures content into reusable objects ‚Äî
home.built15: making it easy to support multiple formats later (like Markdown, HTML, YAML) via clean imports.
home.built16: I could've gone with an off-the-shelf MD parser, but I wanted something more purpose-built and minimal ‚Äî
home.built17: with less magic and more control.
home.built18: This makes the Journal and Sandbox sections more than static blogs ‚Äî
home.built19: they're rendered from structured data that I can query, transform, or re-render any way I want.
home.built20: (For now, all content is managed directly on the file system ‚Äî no database involved.
home.built22: Syntax highlighting is done via Prism, and the layout components are fully modular,
home.built23: making it easy to inject new sections or switch styles as needed.

about.title: About me
about.intro1: That mindset didn't come from tech ‚Äî it came from always wanting to make sense of things by building, not just thinking.
about.intro2: The Greeks said *"techne"* was more than craft ‚Äî
about.intro3: it was a way of understanding the world by making.
about.intro4: That still makes sense to me.
about.philosophy: I like building things ‚Äî not just coding for the sake of it, but actually figuring out why something should exist before touching the keyboard. I'm not the "move fast and break stuff" type. More like "think it through, then build fast ‚Äî and make sure it doesn't break later." I enjoy finding the cleanest way to solve messy problems. I believe good tools matter, but clear thinking matters more. Also, I probably spend too much time tweaking things no one else notices. And I'm fine with that. If something feels off, I'll refactor it. If something's confusing, I'll simplify it. If it needs to ship, I'll get it done. Simple as that.
about.aboutQuote1: I didn't start in tech. I studied music ‚Äî until I realized I enjoyed tinkering with Linux and building little websites way more than practicing scales.
about.aboutQuote2: Turns out, composing and coding aren't that different: both are about structure, flow, and knowing when to break the rules.
about.stackIntro: Here's a look at the stacks I've chosen so far ‚Äî and the languages I'm currently exploring.
about.stackQuote: Here's a rundown of the stacks I genuinely enjoy working with.
about.modernQuote: Built this site with Next.js + Tailwind. Pretty much my go-to stack these days.
about.experimentalQuote: I usually reach for Astro when someone asks me to whip up a clean site fast. Svelte? Looked easy at first... then it pooped on my expectations.
about.nodeQuote: Might be past its prime, but I still use it a lot ‚Äî still feels fresh and exciting every time.
about.legacyQuote: The APM was the first combo I met when I stepped into the world of code. It was already legacy back then ‚Äî now, it feels more like a trace left behind in time.
about.languagesQuote: I've been eyeing Go for its solid rep, and Python... well, still not sure where it fits in.
about.uiQuote: Been rocking Less for like a decade. Still hits different. Bootstrap feels legacy, but hey ‚Äî they're still shipping updates.
about.databasesQuote: I prefer seals over dolphins. Elephants? Still too much, every time.
about.infraQuote: Kinda obsessed with serverless stuff lately ‚Äî Vercel's been a game changer.
about.toolsQuote: Affinity Designer is way cheaper than Illustrator ‚Äî and honestly, it's the only tool I've ever gotten 100x my money's worth from.
about.othersQuote: Once cutting-edge, now just tech fossils I used to swear by. Wild fact: jQuery actually released version 4 in 2025.
